Posts.Content: Great venting: way to go... Any of us, at sometime, have felt much like you did when you vented today. Tomorrow is another day and with it hope for a better day. A big hug and positive thoughts are coming your way.We have your back Pink sister.It certainly does suck to have BC. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: Because some things aren't suitable for Facebook...

Posts.Content: Thanks Ritzy for taking us with you on the relay for life. It's ok to get emotional. The first Memory walk I took after my Dad passed was a tough one. When I walk this year, in the Komen walk/run, it will be my first one as a survivor. All these years I have walked in honor of my Mom. This year, I walk for me and all of the Pink Warriors at CSN.I will be looking for a relay for life in my area. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: Going To My First RELAY FOR LIFE --- My UPDATE On How It Went! :)))))

Posts.Content: Thanks Ritzy for taking us with you on the relay for life. It's ok to get emotional. The first Memory walk I took after my Dad passed was a tough one. When I walk this year, in the Komen walk/run, it will be my first one as a survivor. All these years I have walked in honor of my Mom. This year, I walk for me and all of the Pink Warriors at CSN.I will be looking for a relay for life in my area. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: Going To My First RELAY FOR LIFE --- My UPDATE On How It Went! :)))))

Posts.Content: I didn't know that what we write here could show up on Facebook. I put the name I use here on these boards in the "search" box on facebook and at the bottom of the search results it showed links to these discussion boards with thngs I had written in the past about my lymphedema and breast swelling. To say the least, it was unsettling... since what I openly discuss here on these boards is not what I would so freely disclose to my coworkers, acquintances and neighbors. Has anyone else tried this on Facebook and found the same thing? Since my user names are similar on these boards, I guess it is possible that someone could make the connection. Thought I'd just let everyone know about my finding. It won't stop me from posting but I will be more mindful of what I will wtite. In hind sight, it would have been better to pick two totally differ names for Facebook and these boards. K
Posts.Title: Learned something about Facebook that I didn't know

Posts.Content: This is referred to as an anniversary reaction. Often we "remember" traumatic events in this way. Just need to acknowledge the past: loss, pain and suffering, stay in the moment ( We are now cancer free) and find something to make ourselves feel better (ex: lunch or dinner with friends, a movie, fun with the family or helping others). My one year anniversary comes early in the New Year. I don't plan to commemorate it however I will probably become "aware of it" as the day arrives. I have done this with anniversary dates of my best friend's death and those of my parents. Hang in there and enjoy life in the moment. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: Strange day, strange feeling

Posts.Content: I was told that I might experience SE at or after the first month. I have some stiffness at the ankles and feet when I wake up or sit for long periods of time. It goes away once I am up and active. I did not have these symptoms prior to taking the Arimidex. The only other SE I have experienced is some blurred vision from dry eye that is now under control since beginning the OTC, Genteal lubricant drops once or twice a day.I have maintained my active lifestyle-lots of walking and working long hours (full time). If you have questions, call your Med Onc's office. You don't have to wait until your next appointment. I am told that there are supplements that can help with the joint pain and stiffness. It was recommended that I do daily walking for at least half hour perods (I normally do much more than this.)My nutritionist also suggested I start the vitamin B100s the week I started the Arimidex. Keep us posted. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: QUESTIONS RE: ARIMIDEX & SIDE EFFECTS

Posts.Content: Thanks again Chen for repeating the Hogwarts analogy. It is a good one and bears repeating. Hugs,K
Posts.Title: I was asked to post this occasionally~ the start of a New Year seems like the right time for our New BC board Family Members

Posts.Content: Started ARimidex two weeks after completing my radiation treatment. I am on it for the five year course. I read last night that in some cases, it is taken for 7 or more years. My Med onc mentioned this as a possibilty when she first spoke to me about the Arimidex saying that at this time, the research suggests five years although future investigations may support a longer course of this treatment to decrease the likelihood of the estrogen positive cancers from returning. As to your question about the rate of reoccurrence in those taking the hormone receptor blockers, I wonder how many of those reporting reoccurrences are really reoccurrence of the same cancer or a new cancer occurrence. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: reoccurance question

Posts.Content: I had a fabulous time on Sunday. We ended up taking the shorter walking course for "Survivors" because my husband's hip was bothering him with the damp and wet weather we had that morning.I was a little disappointed that I did not get to walk the full course, as I have done in the past, before my diagnosis. I decided not to let this disappointment interfere with my enjoyment of the experience. The sun came out and the "Survivor parade" and "Survivor Group Photos" were powerful, emotional experiences. The size of the group was huge. Dr Oz made a lovely and inspirational presentation about the growing number of survivors and the improvement in early diagnosis and treatment over the last twenty years.He of course stressed the need for research to cure the beast. Afterward, we went out to a great place for brunch where we were treated with lots of special attention and care by the staff who recognized my team cap (the hospital where I work and receive my treatment) and the very obvious "Survivor" label on the crown. The best part of the day was the satisfaction that I acheived my donation goal and was able to "give back" to others who are currently receiving treatment and those yet to be diagnosed and treated, not only by walking to increase BC awareness but by my involvement in Komen sponsered research on quality of life in BC Survivors. Hope to post some pictures by the end of the week when I get time after work. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: Walked on Sunday in Komen Walk -Run in Central Park

Posts.Content: I am so happy for your good news at your six month checkup. Dance and party, celebrate and plan for fun times ahead. I have my six month check up this month. Keeping my fingers crossed and hoping I can join you in the dance with NED. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: And the News Just Gets Better

Posts.Content: I had my simulation yesterday. It was a long process but not horrible. I am also having it given IMRT and I have chosen the prone rather than supine position although they did make the cast for the supine position and marked me for both in case I have a preference for one over the other. Being someone who likes to sleep on my abdomen, I didn't find the prone position, at all uncomfortable and actually almost fell asleep. The tatooing of the marks was painless, only felt a mild pinch for the ones on my back. I came home looking for them and they are really hard to find if you aren't looking for them. My simulation last for a little over two hours. Scheduling the daily doses took a long time as the time slots I needed were full. I met with the nurses who gave me inforamtoin about skin care and gave me a jar of Aquaphor cream. They encouraged me to call or meet with them as much as needed with any questions or concerns. So far, if all goes well, I will be getting treatment from 5/13-6/11. I opted for the shorter course with higher rads (also boosters)I go for my PLan-check on 5/13 followed by my first rad treatment. Like you, I want this over as soon as possible. Yes, I am anxious about it and looking forward to dancing with NED. Keep us updated and I will do the same. K

Posts.Title: Update First visit to Radiation Onc

Posts.Content: I am so sorry that so much is happening so quickly to your family. Speak to Mom and Dad's docs and find out if they are eligible for any assistance in the home such as a homemaker or visiting nurse services (transport services to and from appointments might be helpful too). Both of them are going to require long term treatment and support. You have your hands full and need to take care of yourself. Hugs and positive thoughts coming your way, K
Posts.Title: First Mom then Dad

Posts.Content: I will be starting Armidex in June. I just started radiation tx. My medical onc warned me of the possible joint and muscle pain. I am so sorry you have to deal with such misery. I am keeping you in my thoughts for good results on your Mammo. Hope your doc has another medication that does not cause you such pain. Keep us posted. Hugs, Kay
Posts.Title: Arimidex.

Posts.Content: I am post menopausal by a few years.I have osteopenia already but before beginning Arimidex, they ordered another to provide them with a baseline before beginning the new medication.It was also recommended that I begin increased Vit D and Calcium supplements.
Posts.Title: Muscle Girls... was a Bone Density Test recommended for You?

Posts.Content: Might be a good idea to speak with pharmacist in the meantime and see what is available over the counter until you check with your Onc. Hugs,K
Posts.Title: Moisturizing eyedrops

Posts.Content: This is over- the- counter and recommended by my Retinal specialist: Genteal,moderate strength.CHeck with your Oncology provider just to be sure these would be adequate for your needs.It comes in three strengths. I purchased mine at Walgreens. The local CVS did not have them. Hope this helps. Hugs,K
Posts.Title: Moisturizing eyedrops

Posts.Content: I am trying to get an evaluation for the swelling in my left arm. I had six nodes removed,with my lumpectomy, all nodes came out negative for Cancer.I hear that there is also research being done at NYU. I have contacted them for the physical therapy/occupational therapy evaluation for lymphedema. They have a three week waiting list before scheduling. That seems good compared to the other hospitals that I have contacted over the past week who have waiting lists that go to the end of the summer. The lymphedema specialists are either a rare commodity here in NYC or I have picked the wrong time to be seeking this service.Thanks for sharing your videos and information. It sure sounds like the UK and Australia are ahead of us in this area of scientific investigation. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: I am taking part in a Lymphedema research study

Posts.Content: Hi Meena, Just dropping you a note to let you know I am thinking about you and sending positive thoughts and prayers your way. Hugs, K
Posts.Title: For Meena1

Posts.Content: Dear SunnieC, I had lumpectomy, sentinal node and removal of 6 nodes with no node involvment, clear margins and 3mm sized mass. I was offered the standard treatment of approximately six weeks of radiation or the more intense 21 day schedule with boosters. I believe that the shorter, more intense course of treatment is done more often in Canada, some Brazil and Europe. This shorter course of treatment has become standard practice in several countries. Several Cancer centers here in NYC have been offering it for more than 10 years. I checked the research and the results appear about the same as the longer course in regard to prognosis and side effects.Speak to your Oncologist about it. Differences in machines, your doctor's clinical judgement and the facility's protocols will also influence what choices are available in regard radiation treatments. Hang in there. All the best. KayNYC
Posts.Title: Rads question...

Posts.Content: It will be one year since my lumpectomy in March 2011. Yes, I am still tender in the area of the incision due to the scar tissue from surgery and from rad treatments. If I lean over and bang into something or accidentally get bumped, I really feel it. The shooting pains, sort of like little shocks that went straight to the nipple have stopped.I still have an area on the back and underside of my underarm (axilla) that is numb. Breast swelling is much less now but it is due to lymphedema in the breast and upper arm below the sentinal node excision site.My Medical Oncologist and surgeon say this is all expected as they are "post surgical changes"= scar tissue. Hugs,K
Posts.Title: Breast still tender 1yr later after lumpectomy
